CN.content:
Please identify the "Material Name" entities in the following paragraph. Please present the valid entities as a Markdown table with one column "Material Name". Make sure to present the entities precisely in the same words as in the original paragraph.

Paragraph: The ratios between the hole and electron mobilities were calculated to be 3.2 and 13.6 for the POBDTPD : PC 70 BM blend and the PEBDTPD : PC 70 BM blend films , respectively. The less balanced carrier transport in the PEBDTPD : PC 70 BM blend film accounts for the lower FF. The polymers and polymer blend films were also analyzed by X-ray diffraction ( XRD ) studies. Figure 8 shows the XRD patterns of the polymers and the polymer : PC 70 BM blends. All film XRD results were similar and showed weak crystalline features with a broad peak around 23 ° . The crystalline features corresponding to π-stacking among the conjugated polymer backbones were also observed among TT - based polymers ; 25 however , the peaks were broader , and no crystalline peaks were observed at smaller angles around 4.4 ° . This less crystalline feature was possibly caused by the more twisted polymer backbones , as compared to PTB7 or PBDTTPD polymer backbones . In conclusion , we synthesized the low band gap POBDTPD and PEBDTPD polymers that consist of dialkoxybenzodithiophene ( BDT ) as the donor and N-octyl-2,7-dithia-5azacyclopenta[a]pentalene-4,6-dione ( DTPD ) as the acceptor. The DTPD acceptor moieties allow the POBDTPD and PEBDTPD polymers to have a low band gap ( ∼ 900 nm ) and optimal HOMO and LUMO levels alignment for PSCs , yielding the PCEs of 4.7 and 5.3% , respectively. In this study , we demonstrate , for the first time , that the DTPD unit is a promising electron - withdrawing building block for low band gap polymers , and it can be utilized to tailor the optical and electronic properties of conjugated polymers for photovoltaic devices and many other applications in plastic electronics.

Let's think step by step.

| Material Name |
| --- |
| POBDTPD |
| PEBDTPD |
| PC 70 BM |
| TT |
| PTB7 |
| PBDTTPD |
| BDT |
| DTPD |

Note:

* POBDTPD and PEBDTPD are the names of specific polymers used in the study.
* PC 70 BM is a type of polymer blend.
* TT is a type of polymer.
* PTB7 and PBDTTPD are other polymers mentioned in the study for comparison.
* BDT and DTPD are building blocks or moieties used in the synthesis of the polymers.

The less balanced carrier transport in the PEBDTPD : PC 70 BM blend film accounts for the lower FF. The polymers and polymer blend films were also analyzed by X-ray diffraction ( XRD ) studies. The crystalline features corresponding to π-stacking among the conjugated polymer backbones were also observed among TT - based polymers ; 25 however , the peaks were broader , and no crystalline peaks were observed at smaller angles around 4.4 ° . This less crystalline feature was possibly caused by the more twisted polymer backbones , as compared to PTB7 or PBDTTPD polymer backbones . | Property Value | Description |
| --- | --- |
| 3.2 | Ratio of hole and electron mobilities for POBDTPD:PC 70 BM blend |
| 13.6 | Ratio of hole and electron mobilities for PEBDTPD:PC 70 BM blend |
| 23° | Angle of broad peak in XRD patterns of polymers and polymer blends |
| 4.4° | Angle of crystalline peak in XRD patterns of TT-based polymers |
| 900 nm | Band gap of POBDTPD and PEBDTPD polymers |
| 4.7% | PCE of POBDTPD:PC 70 BM blend |
| 5.3% | PCE of PEBDTPD:PC 70 BM blend |

Note: PCE stands for power conversion efficiency.
